data.title: WTVR CBS 6 News wins coveted Outstanding News Operation of the Virginias award from Associated Press
data.meta_description: In addition to being named Outstanding News Operation, WTVR CBS 6 was honored with 13 first or second-place award in 11 other categories:
data.text:
For the second year in a row, WTVR CBS 6 News was named Outstanding News Operation of the Virginias at the 2023 Associated Press Broadcasters Awards Saturday at The Greenbrier Resort in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia.

"WTVR stood out in the way they advanced important stories in their breaking news coverage, their work in using videos and natural sound to add context to all their stories, and their investigative storytelling," the judges wrote. "Of particular note--their innovative coverage of crime in greater Richmond with their 360 degree look at 6pm; and their unique and engaging weather content storytelling. Watching WTVR's submission showcased consistent excellence and captured the spirt of 'who they are' as a news organization."

In addition to being named Outstanding News Operation, WTVR CBS 6 was honored with 13 first or second-place award in 11 other categories:

Outstanding News Operation of the Virginias: First, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA.

Best Team News Coverage: Second, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “UVA Shootings.”

Best Reporter: First, Laura French, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA.

Best Producer: First, Mike Bergazzi, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Crime 360.”

Best Spot News Photography: First, Joe Valdez, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “What Are They Going to Do?”; Second, Ben Brady, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Tappahannock Fire.”

Best Light Feature:Second, Greg McQuade and Curtis Akers, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Mystery Letters in the Attic: It Is Definitely a Love Story.”

Outstanding Sports Operation of the Virginias: First, Lane Casadonte and Sean Robertson, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA.

Best Sports Feature: First, Greg McQuade and Brad Wilson, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Gowdy Gloves: Maybe This Is the Way I Get to the Show.”

Best Weathercaster: Second, Zach Daniel, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA.

Best Weathercast: Second, Zach Daniel, Mike Stone and Chris Munnings, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Cold Water Weather.”

Best Documentary or In-Depth:Second, David Stotts, Jon Burkett and Brandy Brown, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Crime Insider Reopen the Case.”

Best Station Promo: First, Brandy Brown, David Stotts and Victoria Bostic, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Crime Insider Reopen the Case”; Second, David Stotts, Kaci Taylor and Rob Byrne, WTVR-TV, Richmond, VA, “Backyard Weather All Year Long.”

Thirty-nine news organizations in Virginia and West Virginia submitted 709 entries in the contest, which featured news and sports stories from 2022.

The VAPB is an independent association comprised of local members of The Associated Press, a not-for-profit news cooperative that represents thousands of newspapers and broadcast stations across the United States.

The VAPB also awarded two $2,000 scholarships to students majoring in media and broadcast journalism: Tolulope Olasoji of West Virginia University and Avalon Pernell of Washington and Lee University.
